\par Sutton, Ne. 68979

\par For further information contact: }{\ul Don George or Doug George}{: Plant Managers.

\par 

\par Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

\par 

\par 1.  The Facility Policy

\par 

\par \tab 

The owners, management, and employees of George Bros. Propane & Fertilizer Corp. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire 

company, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

\par 

\par  2.  Facility Information.

\par 

\par \tab The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.

\par 

\par \tab Anhydrous ammonia is received , stored, and distributed  for direct application for crop nutrients.

\par 

\par \tab The maximum quantity stored would be 459,000 lbs. in our storage tank and nurse trailers.  The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a semi trailer holding  50,350 lbs. 

\par 

\par  3.  The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.

\par

\par  \tab a.  The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank (or trailer) released as a gas over 10 minutes.  t

he maximum quantity released would be 140,200 lbs, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by design standards and administrative controls.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is

 4.4 miles.

\par 

\par \tab b.  The alternative release scenario based on the five-year accident history (or the most likely potential incident) is a release from a break in a transfer hose.  the distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .5 mile.

\par 

\par 4.  The accidental release prevention program.

\par 

\par \tab The facility has implemented the provisions of "safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the standards 

of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia."

\par 

\par  5.  The Five-year Accident History 

\par 

\par \tab a.  There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:

\par 

\par        - have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the 

\par           facility; nor

\par 

\par        - to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations,

\par           sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

\par 

\par  6.  The emergency response program.

\par 

\par \tab The facility has

\par 

\par \tab a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 

\par                 29 CFR 1910.38;

\par 

\par \tab b.  provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community

\par                  right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

\par 

\par \tab c.  a written emer

gency response program, in accordance with OSHA standard, 

\par                  29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

\par 

\par 7.  Planned changes to improve safety.

\par 

\par \tab Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.



\par 

\par }}
